events.target_title: Not information available for cities of Peru
large file throughput via gvfs-smb is over 2x slower than smbclient or fstab mount.cifs

note.body:
Tested different protocols, tested with iperf, swapped USB drives, changed boards from USB 2 to USB 3 (just raspis), changed all sorts of samba server config.

Months of intermittent head scratching before I finally found out it was a client issue! Longer than I care to admit. How could my comparably powerful client ever be the bottleneck!?

I did notice a weird behavior, though.

When the client's NIC is otherwise idle, the transfer caps at about 3MBytes/s. When I'm doing other substantial traffic, eg, over 50mpbs, the gvfs-smb transfer will often increase to 10MBytes/s.

(Client is an up to date Ubuntu 18.04)

events.target_title: Enhanced remote resource (image, movies, etc) whitelisting/blocking support

note.body:
I understand why automatically whitelisting senders that exist in the user's address book may be a desirable feature for many users, but I still feel it would be important to have a way to opt-out globally (this is an option, for example, in gmail: contacts are whitelisted by default, but it is possible to opt-out and decide about the loading of remote images in each single message). 

In my work, I interact with people who use services such as mailtrack dot io that use images to track if/when I open an email. Currently, if I use Geary, I have no way to check my email privately without sharing this information with them. Removing those contacts from my address book would be impractical, because, after all, I still need to contact them.

In brief, I feel this would be important to improve privacy protection (see also https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/geary/issues/159).

I might agree with your opinion, but a) the maximum value is currently somehow arbitrary and b) the way it currently works requires experimenting to find out what the actually possible maximum value is.

One doesn't need high values for "normal" sharpening actions, of course, but once you need extreme sharpness in layer masks or dedicated layers for special purposes, the current functionality is a PITA. I actually stumbled across the issue while writing a tutorial in which I needed both a hyper-sharpened layer and a corresponding layer mask to fix an image with overexposed areas.

note.body:
I can confirm this happens as well, I'm also running F31 in Gnome on Wayland.  I'll also add that it seems to only happen when mixing port types.  For example, I have the following setup:

HDMI-1 = Dell 1600x900
DVI-1 = HP 1920x1080
DVI-2 = HP 1920x1080

With HDMI-1 plugged in when I lock the screen AND the displays go into power saving mode (power off) and then I unlock the screen the windows are a complete mess, presumably randomly scattered across the first screen to wake up.  If I disable HDMI-1 (unplug it from the desktop) then this problem goes away and my windows stay where they were before I locked the screen.  Let me know if I can provide any other info to help with this.

This might be related to [Cinnamon issue 5487](https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/issues/5487) and [Unity bug 1295267](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/unity/+bug/1295267)

note.body:
I had the exact same problem for the very same task, using Gtk+3.24.10 on Mate desktop.

The toolkit seems to silently ignore **<Super>** bindings, which is not very nice to the user. Super is not considered by GdkX11Keymap to be a modifier on PRIMARY_ACCELERATOR or NO_TEXT_INPUT intents. However there are no warning or errors when you try to use it in a css file.

Here is a patch that fixes it.[fix-super-bindings.patch](/uploads/fe84ef7bae7e947a6fe70a96645ef4e8/fix-super-bindings.patch)

events.target_title: text resize (ctrl and + or ctrl and-) resizes terminal window instead of text
text resize (ctrl and + or ctrl and-) resizes terminal window instead of text

note.body:
While resizing, the terminals behave like this:
**gnome-terminal**
does not resize text, only resizes the window, this is a huge annoyance, since gnome-termial in most other regards is quite good. Text resize is, for my part, mostly used to highlight some text snippet on a 13" 4k monitor, for colleagues, because it's hard to see the text at great distances with that resolution. When this is done, I have to resize the window, to get the text larger, then manually resize the window back down to it's original size, due to it otherwise blocking the other windows on the screen.
**Terminology**
Text resize as expected, snaps the window to the nearest whole character size.
**Terminator**
Resizes the text, if it doesn't fit perfectly with a intiger value of characters, then there is a small gap on the far side.

text resize (ctrl and + or ctrl and-) resizes terminal window instead of text

note.body:
Btw. I don't care if the window resizes smoothly or flips a few px on each resize, as long as the window size is approx the same and the text size changes in the expected direction.
In other words, I care about the functionality, and much less about the aesthetics(Shiny doesn't always equal practical and productive.

note.body:
Thanks for you constructive reply.
Terminology also takes original size into account, so if you resize alot, it will keep within a fraction of a character-width.

As a consultant on the go, I find that the best compromise between weight and screen-realestate is to have a 13" laptop with 4k screen + an asus zenscreen 1080p, this makes for some resizing scenarios, in adition to my first example.
At the office, I'm just fine with a 34" and if that was all I had to use, I wouldn't have created this issue :)

I find it quite interesting how you describe the aesthetics in relation to being productive. I get the same feeling, but with "cludder" actions, such as having to readjust windows, because I for some reason need the text in it to be a different size for some time.

Firefox and Chromium also resize the content of the window without changing the size of the window itself.

I know that Gnome stereotypicly want to avoid any options if at all possible, but would there be a chance to add an option to not resize the window when the text is resized ?

events.target_title: GIMP 2.10.2 becomes really slow from time to time

note.body:
I got to that point too. (using GIMP 2.10.14)
The loading of the file with lots of grouped layers took longer and longer.
Also changing a layer took more time the further down in the layer tree it is placed. Editing the topmost layer in no layer sub group is nearly instant.
Since I figured this out I keep "[ ] Enable layer group previews" disabled to be able to edit my UHD textures faster.
(Setting in Edit > Preferences > Interface aka "User Interface" > Previews)

Reproduce: Use large files with "Enable layer group previews" enabled. 
E.g. Import, convert and play around with the layers of this UHD textures: https://forums.eagle.ru/showpost.php?p=3837660

I dunno what function is used to calculate the preview but it blocks the whole interface and may lead to a windows grey out (not responding window) unless the calculations are done. The preview is quite nice tho. This make me think it is not just some simple pixel matrix of the preview collecting the nearest pixels of the big layers but maybe a detailed downsapling method calculating all the UHD changes of all the layers step by step.
A simpler function and maybe a asynchronus calculation for the layer preview (or a setting to choose both) would be very nice.

this issue might be relatet to https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/issues/2283 and https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/issues/1293

Seems like this defect can be closed since the rsvg-view has been removed as have the gtk3 hard-coded bits of configure:

commit 522aeee0ca9b4ff3940bea2d13ebb77ec6c064a6
Author: Federico Mena Quintero <federico@gnome.org>
Date:   Tue Jul 2 13:06:33 2019

    Remove GTK3 bits from configure.ac

commit 44f8524f4492b7d91c2360a12843a66efe9f04fd
Author: Federico Mena Quintero <federico@gnome.org>
Date:   Tue Jul 2 12:58:56 2019

    Remove rsvg-view.c and its Makefile stuff
    
    Rsvg-view is a pretty crappy SVG viewer.
    
    Also, it adds a GTK dependency on librsvg.  This makes the whole
    dependency graph awkward, since GTK indirectly depends on librsvg via
    gdk-pixbuf.
    
    I think we are better off encouraging people to use image viewers that
    are actually well-written and pleasant to use, like EOG.

note.body:
I vote for this, while using the shift modifier works to open/close folders, I (and possibly many others) am very familiar with using all 4 cursor keys, without shift, to navigate tree-view widgets in GTK desktops.
With that in mind, the close folder action should work when a child is selected, if the child is an open folder, the child folder should be close on first press, then the parent on the second press.

My preference would be to not need the shift modifier for this, as this is more inline with ncdu, and nearly every other tree navigator i've come across... but this could always be a user setting!

events.target_title: New search behavior using type-ahead search by default

note.body: I just switched to a new Ubuntu version and realized (a bit late) that the type-ahead feature is no longer the norm. I'm all in favor of bringing type-ahead back or having a way to let the user choose the desired behavior. And as an example of how important is this navigational feature is, consider the file saving dialog. Right now, when you save a file, you can use the type-ahead feature to quickly move to the destination directory. This implementation has not changed. So now there is an inconsistency for the user. When saving a file I can use type-ahead. But when using nautilus to check a folder content, type-ahead does not work.

I could craft a toy PDF that makes use of the link zoom flags but can't imagine any real world use case. The flags provided by the standard are unusable and when used it's user mistake and not intention.

events.target_title: Make librsvg more relaxed on missing filter definitions
font-size not computed correctly from parent element

note.body:
Thanks! In this case the default font-size is not an issue. 
The SVG element has `class="st3"` where `font-size:12px`. The text element has `class="st2"` where `font-size:0.833336em`. Since there are no other font-sizes defined on text element parents, the resulting font-size shall be 12*0.833336

events.target_title: Make librsvg more relaxed on missing filter definitions

note.body:
By filter chain I understand something like that:

`<rect x="20" y="20" width="100" height="100" fill="#ff0000" filter="url(#blur) url(#hue-rotate)"/>`

Here's a sample "filter chain" file from gecko tests:

https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mozilla/gecko-dev/master/layout/reftests/svg/filters/svg-filter-chains/simple-chain.svg

But the specification doesn't say anything about that other object's styles like fill, stroke, etc. shall be ignored if a filter definition is missing. It is just about the filter and the filter chain.

So the attached file is rendered in Chrome, but not in Firefox.

events.target_title: Provide easy access to the "Enter Location" feature/mode of Nautilus for the new user

note.body:
Ctrl+L feature is good but it is hidden and keyboard only.
It would be nice to be able to do the same think with mouse, and to discover it without googling.
`org.gnome.nautilus.preferences always-use-location-entry` isn't the same, it forces the application in one mode only, while the breadcrumb and the location copy/edit location mode are both critical features.

events.target_title: Provide easy access to the "Enter Location" feature/mode of Nautilus for the new user

note.body:
Use cases :
- I want to go to a location a colleague gave me on slack/I found on a forum. I don't know about Ctrl+L. I have to go manually to the correct path instead of a simple right-click -> paste.
- I want to send a relative directory path from nautilus to someone. I go to the directory, right click on the breadcrumb, then click "copy" (doesn't exists). I enter edit location bar, then select only the part I want and right-click > copy.
- I want to go to a file opened in an IDE which doesn't have the feature to open a file in nautilus. I copy a relative path (to the project), then open nautilus at the project location, copy/paste the path and edit the path (with the keyboard) if necessary before validating.

Most of these actions could be done using only mouse.

events.target_title: Adding a "New"-Button like Snipping-tool in Windows
GIMP doesn't properly remove image data when an alpha channel is supported

note.body:
There is no way to truly **delete** a pixel (selection) from the common bitmap formats. To keep the image consistently rectangular and gapless, every pixel needs to have a RGBA value (OK, with floating point values one could save NaNs, but I digress...). So words like **delete**, **erase**, etc. are *all* misleading if taken verbatim. Consequentially, one has to realize that **erase** will just set some or all of the RGBA values of the pixels (in the selection) to a predefined value.

I am torn whether the GIMP project should assume that users of its software have such basic understanding of how image formats and tools work. Though I'd err on the side that if you have "simple" needs, use "simple" tools, or spend time to learn the tools you want to use. On the other hand, non-surprising defaults are also a good idea for such a project. Is it more worthwhile to keep the default behavior in the way its current users got used to and expect, or make it more "safe" for new users with the specific need to redact parts of an image?

Edit:
Actually what I also meant is: releasing the mouse to hit '+' or '-' is very awkward. Btw., my other hand/arm is supporting my position all this time, so has to be taken out of the equation.

And finally: I came here because I was trying to see if I can add a **default** zoom factor of 60%; I am presently scanning a lot of documents that for me have an optimal zoom factor at 60%. Maybe we could add an option in Preferences to add a **custom** **default** zoom factor?

events.target_title: mpv on Wayland: vsync spikes and mistimed frames causing stutter

note.body: I've only done very limited testing with mutter but I'm not able to reproduce this (RX 550, mutter 3.34.3 and mpv 0.32.0-78-g83efdb5a01). The only thing I've noticed is that Mutter isn't quite so great with fresh frames that take longer than 16.666 ms (slightly high vsync jitter and the display fps isn't steady), but that would be fixable with presentation time. Without trying to push the rendering settings up, it stays pretty steady at around 0.010 for me which is quite good.

events.target_title: Gimp crashes Xorg on HiDPI screen

note.body:
Hi, I am in arch linux and as far as I know there are no external packages having debug symbols to install ( like in some other distributions e.g gimp-dbg in ubuntu ). Therefore I compiled gimp turning on debug symbols and posted the logs. I guess I also have to compile gtk and glibc then. 
Thanks for replying, I will try to post it, hope we can pin point the problem.

**EDIT ::**
Gimp is perfectly usable as long as you don't hover the mouse over the canvas. I just scaled some images using only the keyboard and it worked flawlessly. If there is a gimp dialog over the canvas and I move the mouse over it, It does not crash.

events.target_title: Gimp crashes Xorg on HiDPI screen

note.body:
I tried to recompile gtk2 and glib with debug symbols on. No meaningful update on previous stacktrace. Probably I am doing something wrong. 
I do have openCL turned off and it makes no difference. As Liam says its highly likely to be a bug of nvidia drivers. Gimp works correctly when nvidia is turned off (from bios) and I use intel iGPU instead. ( even in hidpi mode )
